intro: Tragacantha longifolia, commonly known as the Persian gum tree, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and long, slender pods. The plant is known for producing a gum that has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a food additive. Its growth habit includes a shrub or small tree form, often found in arid and semi-arid environments. The botanical features of Tragacantha longifolia make it an important species in both ecological and economic contexts.
